articles.headline: Few Answers After an Alert on Takata Airbags
articles.snippet: A National Highway Traffic Safety Administration site that allows drivers to look up a car by vehicle identification number was not responding, and calls were put on hold.
articles.abstract: A National Highway Traffic Safety Administration site that allows drivers to look up a car by vehicle identification number was not responding, and calls were put on hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after federal safety regulators warned owners of recalled vehicles with defective airbags to “act immediately” and get them replaced because they could explode, consumers on Tuesday were left grasping for answers.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Christopher Jensen

articles.headline: After JPMorgan Chase Breach, Push to Close Wall St. Security Gaps
articles.snippet: Regulators are said to be discussing how to improve a critical area of cybersecurity: outside vendors, including law, accounting and marketing firms and even janitorial companies.
articles.abstract: Regulators are said to be discussing how to improve a critical area of cybersecurity: outside vendors, including law, accounting and marketing firms and even janitorial companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: This summer’s huge cyberattack on JPMorgan Chase and a dozen other financial institutions is accelerating efforts by federal and state authorities to push banks and brokerage firms to close some gaping holes in their defenses.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: A Retreat From Weather Disasters
articles.snippet: As the damages wrought by increasingly disruptive weather patterns have climbed around the world, the insurance industry seems to have quietly engaged in what looks a lot like a retreat.
articles.abstract: As the damages wrought by increasingly disruptive weather patterns have climbed around the world, the insurance industry seems to have quietly engaged in what looks a lot like a retreat.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Sandy roared across the Northeastern United States, many homeowners on Long Island — even those who escaped the most damage — often lost their property insurance. The same thing happened in coastal Virginia after Hurricane Katrina, which hit hundreds of miles away along the Gulf Coast.

articles.headline: Marissa Mayer Can Report Growth at Yahoo, but Strategy Is No Clearer
articles.snippet: Strong third-quarter results, including an improved performance by mobile, ended a long pattern of declines at Yahoo.
articles.abstract: Strong third-quarter results, including an improved performance by mobile, ended a long pattern of declines at Yahoo.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Marissa Mayer finally has something, however modest, to crow about.

articles.headline: Fantasizing on the Famous
articles.snippet: “After,” Anna Todd’s wildly popular web novel based on Harry Styles of the boy band One Direction, is being published as a book.
articles.abstract: “After,” Anna Todd’s wildly popular web novel based on Harry Styles of the boy band One Direction, is being published as a book.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some novelists draw on their own experience; others borrow from history, mythology or classic literary tropes. Anna Todd, a 25-year-old debut novelist in Texas, found inspiration in Harry Styles, the tousle-haired heartthrob from the British boy band One Direction.

articles.headline: Enforcer at Treasury Is First Line of Attack Against ISIS
articles.snippet: David Cohen, a Treasury under secretary, discusses the battle to choke off the flow of illicit revenue to the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: David Cohen, a Treasury under secretary, discusses the battle to choke off the flow of illicit revenue to the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every morning David S. Cohen descends into a fortified, cavelike complex in the bowels of the Treasury Department to pore through hundreds of pages of leads — from raw intelligence reports to polished threat assessments — to try to penetrate the vast and opaque finances of the Islamic State, the terrorist group capable of producing 50,000 barrels of oil a day.

articles.headline: Ben Bradlee, Washington Editor and Watergate Warrior, Dies at 93
articles.snippet: Mr. Bradlee, a quintessential newspaper editor, supervised The Washington Post’s exposure of the Watergate scandal that led to the resignation of President Richard M. Nixon.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bradlee, a quintessential newspaper editor, supervised The Washington Post’s exposure of the Watergate scandal that led to the resignation of President Richard M. Nixon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ben Bradlee, who presided over The Washington Post’s Watergate reporting that led to the fall of President Richard M. Nixon and that stamped him in American culture as the quintessential newspaper editor of his era — gruff, charming and tenacious — died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 93.

articles.headline: States Ease Interest Rate Laws That Protected Poor Borrowers
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in several states have voted to increase the fees or the interest rates that lenders can charge on personal loans used by millions of poor or financially struggling borrowers.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in several states have voted to increase the fees or the interest rates that lenders can charge on personal loans used by millions of poor or financially struggling borrowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lenders have come under fire in Washington in recent years. Yet one corner of the financial industry — lending to people with poor credit scores — has found sympathetic audiences in many state capitals.

articles.headline: New Freedoms in Tunisia Drive Support for ISIS
articles.snippet: Even as Tunisians have approved a new constitution and the country has one of the Arab world’s most educated populations, militants are recruiting more openly there than in any other country.
articles.abstract: Even as Tunisians have approved a new constitution and the country has one of the Arab world’s most educated populations, militants are recruiting more openly there than in any other country.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Nearly four years after the Arab Spring revolt, Tunisia remains its lone success as chaos engulfs much of the region. But that is not its only distinction: Tunisia has sent more foreign fighters than any other country to Iraq and Syria to join the extremist group that calls itself the Islamic State.

articles.headline: Nation’s Confidence Ebbs at a Steady Drip
articles.snippet: With every passing week or month, it seems, some American government agency has had a misstep or scandal that has led to a deeply eroded public confidence.
articles.abstract: With every passing week or month, it seems, some American government agency has had a misstep or scandal that has led to a deeply eroded public confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In taking office during two overseas wars and the Great Recession, President Obama set out to restore society’s frayed faith in its public institutions, saying that the question was not whether government was too big or small, “but whether it works.” Six years later, Americans seem more dubious than ever that it really does.

articles.headline: Home Solar Power Discounts Are Worker Perk in New Program
articles.snippet: Conceived at the World Wildlife Fund, the initiative uses bulk purchasing power to allow for discounts on home systems.
articles.abstract: Conceived at the World Wildlife Fund, the initiative uses bulk purchasing power to allow for discounts on home systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Expanding the notion of corporate benefits beyond discounted health club memberships and low insurance rates, a group of major companies is set to offer employees access to cheaper solar systems for the home.

articles.headline: Gunman Panics Ottawa, Killing Soldier in Spree at Capital
articles.snippet: Shots fired inside the Parliament building, before the assailant was killed, stoked fears across Canada, a nation already on alert for terrorism.
articles.abstract: Shots fired inside the Parliament building, before the assailant was killed, stoked fears across Canada, a nation already on alert for terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The heart of the Canadian capital was thrown into panic and placed in lockdown on Wednesday after a gunman armed with a rifle or shotgun fatally wounded a corporal guarding the tomb of the unknown soldier at the National War Memorial, entered the nearby Parliament building and fired multiple times before he was shot and killed.
articles.byline: By Ian Austen and Rick Gladstone
